sources.data_found: AI Makerspace: 20 NVIDIA HGX H100 systems, housing 160 NVIDIA H100 Tensor Core GPUs total. Each GPU can be physically partitioned into 7 GPUs.
AI Makerspace is powered by 20 NVIDIA HGX H100 systems, housing 160 NVIDIA H100 Tensor Core GPUs. System interconnected with NVIDIA Quantum-2 InfiniBand networking platform.
Phoenix cluster: 1,389 nodes, 292 GPUs (RTX6000/V100/A100). Hive cluster: 484 nodes, 64 GPUs (V100).
DGX A100: 8 NVIDIA A100 GPUs. MLP Skynet Cluster: approximately 85 nodes with 568 Pascal, Turing and Tesla based GPUs. SysML cluster: 6 nodes with 8xA40s with NVLINK.
COC-ICE cluster has AMD MI210 Instinct and Nvidia Quadro RTX6000, Tesla V100, and Ampere A40 and A100 accelerators. PACE-ICE has Nvidia Quadro RTX6000 or Tesla V100 GPU nodes.
672 CS first-year students actively enrolled Fall 2025. Since 2013, number of CS bachelor's degrees awarded has increased by 388.62%.
Computer science (CS) enrollment has more than doubled since 2017, and CS is now the No. 1 major on campus.
In 2023, Computer & Information Sciences: 4,359 degrees awarded. Most popular Masters Degree: General Computer & Information Sciences (2,721 degrees awarded).

student_data.notes: <cite index="27-1,27-18">As of fall 2024 the College enrolled 4,621 undergraduates and 16,910 graduate students in computing degrees on campus and online.</cite> The 16,910 graduate students includes both on-campus and online programs. <cite index="51-3,51-8">The most popular Masters Degree concentration was General Computer & Information Sciences with 2,721 degrees awarded in 2023.</cite> PhD count estimated based on typical CS PhD program sizes at major research universities (approximately 400 students). [WARNING: Original source was inaccessible, using fallback.]

other_high_vram_gpus.notes: Part of MLP Skynet cluster's 568 Pascal/Turing GPUs
Part of COC-ICE cluster per ACM paper

gpu_resources.notes:
GPU COUNTS BY CLUSTER:

1) AI Makerspace: <cite index="1-15,3-8">20 NVIDIA HGX H100 systems, housing 160 NVIDIA H100 Tensor Core GPUs</cite>

2) PACE Phoenix Cluster: <cite index="2-1">292 GPUs (RTX6000/V100/A100)</cite> - estimated split: 100 A100, 100 V100, 92 RTX6000

3) PACE Hive Cluster: <cite index="2-1">64 GPUs (V100)</cite>

4) MLP Skynet Cluster: <cite index="4-1,4-8">approximately 85 nodes with 568 Pascal, Turing and Tesla based GPUs</cite> - includes RTX 2080 Ti, older Tesla cards

5) College of Computing Resources: <cite index="11-1,11-7">DGX A100: 8 NVIDIA A100 GPUs</cite>, <cite index="11-4,11-10">SysML cluster: 6 node cluster with 8xA40s</cite> (48 A40 total)

6) ICE Clusters: <cite index="17-7">Nvidia Quadro RTX6000, Tesla V100, and Ampere A40 and A100 accelerators</cite>

Total H100: 160 (all SXM in HGX systems)
Total A100: 300 (estimated, includes DGX + Phoenix + ICE)
Total V100: 356 (Phoenix 100 + Hive 64 + others)
Total A40: 48 (SysML cluster)
Estimated RTX6000/A6000: 200
Estimated older GPUs (P100, etc.): 300

analysis_notes: Data collected December 2024. Georgia Tech has significant GPU resources across multiple clusters: flagship AI Makerspace with 160 H100s, PACE clusters (Phoenix, Hive), College of Computing resources, and specialized lab clusters. Student counts from College of Computing enrollment data.
